revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NFL_season | logo = | team = Seattle Seahawks | year = 2009 | record = 5â11 | division_place = 3rd [[NFC West]] | coach = [[Jim L. Mora|Jim Mora]] | stadium = [[Qwest Field]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | uniform = Image:NFCW-Uniform-SEA.PNG }} The '''[[2009 NFL season|2009]] [[Seattle Seahawks]] season''' was the 34th season for the team in the [[National Football League]]. The Seahawks improved in [[Jim L. Mora|Jim Mora]]'s first season as their head coach, after a disappointing 4â12 record and a 3rd place finish in what was [[Mike Holmgren]]'s final season coaching the team. However, Mora was fired January 8, 2010.http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/seattle-seahawks-fire-jim-mora-010810 {{TOC limit|limit=2}} ==Offseason== ===Staff changes=== [[Image:Jim L Mora 2006-11-19.jpg|left|thumb|Jim Mora (shown here with the Atlanta Falcons) was announced as the new Seahawks head coach on January 13.]] {{Quote box | quote =With Jim Mora we are getting a smart, passionate, committed coach to winning and building a successful franchise. | source = â General Manager Tim Ruskell on hiring Jim Mora as head coach.{{cite web | title=Jim Mora Press Conference | url=http://www.seahawks.com/media-lounge/videos/jim-mora-press-conference/52f5a89a-5a95-4f01-94f3-429a5efbe2cd| publisher=Seattle Seahawks | date=2009-01-13 | accessdate=2009-05-23|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5j0vwSWtV|archivedate=2009-08-14|deadurl=no}} | width =33% | align =right }} At the beginning of the [[2008 Seattle Seahawks season|2008 season]], then-head coach [[Mike Holmgren]] stated that 2008 would be his final season before retiring. On December 30, 2008, two days after the season ended, Holmgren officially retired and stepped down as head coach. [[Jim L. Mora|Jim Mora]], the team's assistant head coach and defensive backs coach, was officially selected as his replacement on January 13, 2009. The retirement and Jim Mora's accession had been originally announced on January 22, 2008.{{cite news | title=Mora named Seahawks head coach in 2009 | url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/seahawks/2004166684_hawk060.html | publisher=Seattle Times | date=2008-02-06 | accessdate=2009-05-23|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5j0vwqjY5|archivedate=2009-08-14|deadurl=no | first=Danny | last=O'Neil}} Mora then began to replace most of the staff that Holmgren had last year. Defensive coordinator [[John Marshall]] and defensive line coach [[Dwaine Board]] were both fired on January 12, 2009. Subsequently, former [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] linebackers coach [[Casey Bradley]] was hired as the new defensive coordinator. Also, former [[New York Jets]] assistant [[Dan Quinn]] replaced Board as the defensive line coach and as the new assistant head coach.{{cite web | title=Seahawks hire Bradley from Bucs to be D-Coordinator | url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/11251654 | publisher=CBS Sports | date=2008-01-12 | accessdate=2009-05-24|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5j0vxFE8Q|archivedate=2009-08-14|deadurl=no}} The offensive side was also revamped as well. Offensive coordinator [[Gil Haskell]] was dismissed after 8 years with the Seahawks. Former [[Oakland Raiders]] offensive coordinator [[Greg Knapp]], who had previously worked with Mora when he was the head coach of the [[Atlanta Falcons]], was hired as his replacement on January 14, 2009.{{cite web | title=Seahawks to hire Knapp as coordinator |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80df444e&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true | publisher=National Football League | date=2009-01-24 | accessdate=2009-05-24}} Mora also fired wide receivers coach [[Keith Gilbertson]] and was replaced with former [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] assistant receivers coach Robert Prince. Finally, tight ends coach [[Jim Lind (football)|Jim Lind]] and special teams assistant [[John Jamison]] both retired after the 2008 season. [[Mike DeBord]], formerly the offensive line assistant coach, replaced Lind although no replacement has been named for Jamison. ===Key departures=== Running back [[Maurice Morris]], who backed up starter [[Julius Jones]] last season, signed with the [[Detroit Lions]].{{cite web | title=Morris signs with Lions | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80efeb66&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true | publisher=National Football league | accessdate=2009-02-27}} The Seahawks also lost defensive tackle [[Rocky Bernard]] to the [[New York Giants]].{{cite web | title=Giants Sign DT Rocky Bernard | url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/sports/football/giants/Giants-Sign-Former-Seattle-DT-Rocky-Bernard.html | publisher=NBC New York | accessdate=2009-03-01}} Fan favorite [[Bobby Engram]] was released and signed with the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] after the Seahawks signed wide receiver [[T.J. Houshmandzadeh]]. The Seahawks were also in talks with fullback [[Leonard Weaver]] about a new contract, but ultimately he signed with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] instead. Also, the Seahawks traded away Pro Bowl linebacker [[Julian Peterson]] to the Lions.[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090314/ap_on_sp_fo_ne/fbn_lions_seahawks_trade;_ylt=AndsyYY44ci1X7NnnS96YRkLMxIF Lions Get Peterson in Return for Redding] Yahoo Sports, March 14, 2009 In all, the Seahawks lost a total of 14 players to free agency. [[File:Leroy-Hill-2008-11-02-vsEagles.jpg|right|thumb|Seahawks placed the franchise tag on Linebacker Leroy Hill, but released him to free agency before signing him to a long-term deal.]] Linebacker [[Leroy Hill]] was placed under the [[franchise tag]] on February 19, 2009.{{cite web | title=Seahawks puts franchise tag on Hill | url=http://www.seahawks.com/news/press/article-1/seahawks-place-franchise-tag-on-hill/614739de-3a3d-45dc-bc69-f11b61ceecf9 | publisher=Seattle Seahawks | accessdate=2009-02-19|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5j0vvdaYw|archivedate=2009-08-14|deadurl=no}} However, discussions for a long term deal between Hill and the Seahawks were slow, and they continued to stall up to the draft. In a effort to speed up negotiations. the Seahawks removed their franchise tag on Hill less than 24 hours within the first draft day, thereby releasing him to free agency and allowing him to sign with other teams. However, on April 30, 2009, Hill agreed to a 6-year, 38 million dollar deal with the Seahawks.{{cite web | title=Seahawks resign Leroy Hill to long-term deal | url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlesports/archives/167755.asp| publisher=Seattle Post Intelligence| accessdate=2009-04-30}} Moments after signing [[Edgerrin James]] to a one-year deal, the Seahawks release running back [[T.J. Duckett]] to make room on their roster. Duckett previously led the team in rushing touchdowns last year. Safety [[Brian Russell]] was also released on September 5, 2009.{{cite news|title=Seahawks | Brian Russell out, Lawyer Milloy in as Seahawks free safety | Seattle Times Newspaper |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/seahawks/2009813491_hawk06.html|work=The Seattle Times|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jfcSxpJq|archivedate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-09-07 | first=Danny | last=O'Neil | date=September 6, 2009}} Russell had started at safety for the Seahawks since coming in at the start of the 2007 season. [[Lawyer Milloy]], signed after Russell's departure, is expected to fill his spot along with [[Jordan Babineaux]]. ===Key additions=== The Seahawks made big splashes during the offseason as well. On March 1, Seattle signed defensive tackle [[Colin Cole (American football)|Colin Cole]] from the [[Green Bay Packers]] to a 5-year contract to address problems on their defensive line.[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090302/ap_on_sp_fo_ne/fbn_seahawks_cole;_ylt=Ap2lZLs1O3j0xk.urj.6YgALMxIF DT Cole Agrees to Deal With Seahawks] Yahoo Sports, March 1, 2009 They also received defensive tackle [[Cory Redding]] and a fifth round pick in exchange for the Peterson trade mentioned above. Perhaps the biggest move in free agency, however, was the signing of former Pro Bowl wide receiver [[T.J. Houshmandzadeh]] from the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] to a 5-year, $40 million deal with $15 million guaranteed two days after signing Cole.{{Cite book |last=Clayton |first=John |title=Houshmandzadeh heads West |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3947108 |publisher=ESPN |date=2009-03-02 |accessdate=2009-03-02}} Houshmandzadeh was rated as one of the top free agents available. After rescinding their franchise tag on Hill, the Seahawks signed former [[Carolina Panthers]] corner back [[Ken Lucas (American football)|Ken Lucas]] to a one year deal in order to bolster their pass coverage. They also signed fullback [[Justin Griffith]] from the [[Oakland Raiders]] to address the departure of Weaver.{{cite web | title=Seahawks sign CB Lucas, also agreed to terms with FB Griffith | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d81007005&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true| publisher=National Football League| accessdate=2009-04-30}} It was known that releasing of Hill created some flexibility on the [[salary cap]] of where these two deals go into play. On August 25, 2009, the Seahawks signed running back [[Edgerrin James]] to a 1-year, $2 million dollar deal.{{Cite book |last=Johns |first=Greg |title=Done deal: Seahawks sign Edge, cut Duckett|url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlesports/archives/177421.asp |publisher=Seattle Post Intelligencer |date=2009-08-25 |accessdate=2009-08-30|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jcZuKGjF|archivedate=2009-09-07|deadurl=no}} James last played with division rival [[Arizona Cardinals]] for the past three seasaons and played a vital role in their playoff run last year. The Seahawks also signed veteran safety [[Lawyer Milloy]] to a one-year deal, who is expected to make a big impact to the team.{{Cite book |last=Johns |first=Greg |title=Seahawks sign Milloy, add new offensive tackle|url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlesports/archives/178479.asp|publisher=Seattle Post Intelligencer |date=2009-09-06 |accessdate=2009-09-07|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jfcTSCvh|archivedate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no}} ===2009 NFL Draft=== {| class="wikitable" align="center" |+ 2009 Seattle Seahawks Draft Selections ! Round !! Overall !! Player !! Position !! College |- |1 || 4th||[[Aaron Curry (American football)|Aaron Curry]] ||LB||[[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest]] |- |2 || 49th (from Chicago)||[[Max Unger]] ||C||[[University of Oregon|Oregon]] |- |3 || 91st (from Philadelphia through New York) ||[[Deon Butler]] ||WR||[[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State]] |- |6 || 178th ||[[Mike Teel]] ||QB||[[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] |- |7 || 245th ||[[Courtney Greene]]||S||[[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] |- |7 || 247th ||[[Nick Reed]]||DE||[[University of Oregon|Oregon]] |- |7 || 248th ||[[Cameron Morrah]]||TE||[[University of California|California]] |- |} Seattle traded their 5th round draft pick to the [[Denver Broncos]] for wide receiver [[Keary Colbert]], but received another 5th round draft pick from Detroit. On draft day, the Seahawks traded away their 2nd round pick (37th overall) to the [[Denver Broncos]] for their [[2010 NFL Draft|2010 1st round pick]]. They also traded for [[Chicago Bears|Chicago's]] 2nd round pick (49th overall) in return for both their 3rd and 4th round picks in the draft (68th and 105th respectively). Finally, the Seahawks traded for Philadelphia's 3rd round pick (91st overall) for their 2010 3rd round pick and their 5th and 7th round picks in the draft (137th and 213rd respectively). ==Coaching staff== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background-color: #335487; color: white; text-align: center;"|'''Seattle Seahawks 2009 staff''' |- | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Front Office''' *Chairman â [[Paul Allen]] *CEO â [[Tod Leiweke]] *Vice President of Player Personnel/Interim General Manager â [[Ruston Webster]] *Vice President of Football Administration â [[John Idzik]] *Director of Pro Personnel â [[Will Lewis (American football)|Will Lewis]] *Western Region Director of College Scouting â [[Scott Fitterer]] *Eastern Region Director of College Scouting â [[Mike Yowarsky]] '''Head Coaches''' *Head Coach â [[Jim L. Mora|Jim Mora]] *Assistant Head Coach/Defensive Line â [[Dan Quinn (football coach)|Dan Quinn]] '''Offensive Coaches''' *Offensive Coordinator â [[Greg Knapp]] *Quarterbacks â [[Bill Lazor]] *Running Backs â [[Kasey Dunn]] *Wide Receivers â [[Robert Prince (football coach)|Robert Prince]] *Tight Ends â [[Mike DeBord]] *Offensive Line â [[Mike Solari]] *Offensive Assistant/Assistant Special Teams â [[Chris Beake]] |width="35"|  |valign="top"| | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Defensive Coaches''' *Defensive Coordinator â [[Casey Bradley]] *Assistant Defensive Line â [[Mike Phair]] *Linebackers â [[Zerick Rollins]] *Defensive Backs â [[Tim Lewis]] *Assistant Defensive Backs â [[Larry Marmie]] *Defensive Quality Control â [[Tom Headlee]] '''Special Teams Coaches''' *Special Teams â [[Bruce DeHaven]] '''Strength and Conditioning''' *Head Strength and Conditioning â [[Mike Clark (football coach)|Mike Clark]] *Assistant Strength and Conditioning â [[Darren Krein]] |} ==Team captains== * [[Matt Hasselbeck]] * [[Walter Jones (American football)|Walter Jones]] * [[Lofa Tatupu]] * [[Deon Grant]] * [[Lance Laury]] * [[Olindo Mare]] ==Final roster== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="9" style="background-color: #335487; color: white; text-align: center;"|'''Seattle Seahawks 2009 final roster''' |- | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Quarterbacks''' *  8 [[Matt Hasselbeck]] * 14 ''[[Mike Teel]]'' * 15 [[Seneca Wallace]] '''Running Backs''' * 20 [[Justin Forsett]] KR * 33 [[Justin Griffith]] FB * 22 [[Julius Jones]] * 40 [[Louis Rankin]] * 35 [[Owen Schmitt]] FB '''Wide Receivers''' * 83 [[Deion Branch]] * 81 [[Nate Burleson]] PR * 11 ''[[Deon Butler]]'' * 84 [[T. {{colorbox|#00ff00}} The Seahawks wore their light green jerseys for this game. |- |} ==Standings== {{2009 NFC West standings}} ==Regular season results== ===Week 1: vs. St. Louis Rams=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Rams |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home='''Seahawks''' |H1=0||H2=14||H3=14||H4=0||HT=0 |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/1:15 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 73Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 67,610 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]], [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]], & Rob Desir }} Head Coach [[Jim L. Mora|Jim Mora]] era began his coaching debut for the Seahawks with a game at home against division rival [[St. Louis Rams]]. Quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] and the offense struggled early, turning over the ball three times (two interceptions and one fumble) on the first quarter alone. After Rams kicker [[Josh Brown (American football)|Josh Brown]] missed a 37-yard field goal for the lead, Hasselbeck led the Seahawks to their first score of the game after he connected with tight end [[John Carlson (American football)|John Carlson]] for a touchdown. With the second quarter coming to a close, St. Louis returned a blocked field goal for a touchdown, only to have it overruled by a penalty. This gave another chance for the Seahawks to score, as Hasselbeck threw his second touchdown of the game to [[Nate Burleson]] to put the Seahawks up 14â0 by halftime. When the third quarter started, the Seahawks looked to increase its lead to win the game. Hasselbeck would lead the Seahawks to a 99-yard drive, capping it off 33-yard touchdown pass to Carlson. [[Julius Jones]] would seal the win with a 62-yard touchdown (and rushing 119 in total) run to put Seattle up by 28. The Seahawks defense would shutout the Rams, as they totaled only 247 total yards on offense and forcing two fumbles and three sacks. Seattle moved to 1â0 to start off the season, and beat the Rams for the ninth straight time. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| ! rowspan="2"| Time of Score ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Team ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Player ! rowspan="2"| Yards of Score ! rowspan="2"| PAT ! colspan="2"| Score |- ! align="center"| Seattle ! align="center"| St. Louis |- ! rowspan="2"| Q2 | 5:45 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[John Carlson (American football)|John Carlson]] | 1 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 7 | align="center"| 0 |- | 0:12 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[Nate Burleson]] | 12 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 14 | align="center"| 0 |- ! rowspan="2"| Q3 | 5:02 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[John Carlson (American football)|John Carlson]] | 33 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 21 | align="center"| 0 |- | 3:42 | Seattle | [[Julius Jones]] | 62 yard run | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 28 | align="center"| 0 |} ===Week 2: at San Francisco 49ers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=0||R2=10||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home='''49ers''' |H1=10||H2=3||H3=7||H4=3||HT=0 |stadium= [[Candlestick Park]], [[San Francisco, California]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/1:05 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 68Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,732 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]] & [[Brian Billick]] }} Coming off their shutout home win over the Rams, the Seahawks flew to [[Candlestick Park]] for a Week 2 NFC West showdown with the [[San Francisco 49ers]]. Seattle would trail early in the first quarter as 49ers kicker [[Joe Nedney]] got a 37-yard field goal, along with running back [[Frank Gore]] getting a 79-yard touchdown run. The Seahawks would respond in the second quarter as kicker [[Olindo Mare]] made a 36-yard field goal. San Francisco would reply with Nedney making a 42-yard field goal. As the Seahawks looked to bounced back from the deficit, quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] received an injury as he was hit on the ground by 49ers linebacker [[Patrick Willis]]. Hasselbeck would leave the game with cracked ribs, yet Seattle closed out the half with backup [[Seneca Wallace]] completing a 1-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Julius Jones]]. In the third quarter, the Seahawks deficit quickly increased as on the 49ers' first offensive play of the second half, Gore would explode for an 80-yard touchdown run. San Francisco would close the game out in the fourth quarter as Nedney nailed a 39-yard field goal. With the loss, Seattle fell to 1â1. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Team ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Player ! rowspan="2"| Time of Score ! rowspan="2"| Yards of Score ! rowspan="2"| PAT ! colspan="2"| Score |- ! Seattle ! San Francisco |- ! rowspan="2"| Q1 | San Francisco | [[Joe Nedney]] | 5:38 1st Qtr. | 37 Yard FG | | align="center"| 0 | align="center"| 3 |- | San Francisco | [[Frank Gore]] | 2:36 1st Qtr. | 79 Yard Rush | [[Joe Nedney]] Kick | align="center"| 0 | align="center"| 10 |- ! rowspan="3"| Q2 | Seattle | [[Olindo Mare]] | 10:04 2nd Qtr. | 36 Yard FG | | align="center"| 3 | align="center"| 10 |- | San Francisco | [[Joe Nedney]] | 2:57 2nd Qtr. | 42 yard FG | | align="center"| 3 | align="center"| 13 |- | Seattle | [[Seneca Wallace]] to [[Julius Jones]] | 0:22 2nd Qtr. | 1 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] Kick | align="center"| 10 | align="center"| 13 |- ! rowspan="1"| Q3 | San Francisco | [[Frank Gore]] | 14:49 3rd Qtr. | 80 yard rush | [[Joe Nedney]] kick | align="center"| 10 | align="center"| 20 |- ! rowspan="1"| Q4 | San Francisco | [[Joe Nedney]] | 6:53 4th Qtr. | 39 yard FG | | align="center"| 10 | align="center"| 23 |} ===Week 3: vs. Chicago Bears=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bears''' |R1=0||R2=7||R3=10||R4=8||RT=25 |Home=Seahawks |H1=10||H2=3||H3=0||H4=6||HT=19 |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/1:05 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 61Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 67,938 |referee= [[Don Carey (official)|Don Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} Hoping to rebound from their divisional road loss to the 49ers, the Seahawks went home, donned their alternate uniforms, and prepared for a Week 3 duel with the [[Chicago Bears]]. Due to quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]]'s rib injury, [[Seneca Wallace]] got the start for the game. Seattle would take flight in the first quarter with Wallace's 39-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Julius Jones]] and kicker [[Olindo Mare]]'s 46-yard field goal. The Seahawks would tack on Mare's 37-yard field goal in the second quarter, yet the Bears would answer with quarterback [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]]'s 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Greg Olsen (American football)|Greg Olsen]]. Chicago would take in the lead in the third quarter with Cutler's 7-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Johnny Knox]], followed by kicker [[Robbie Gould]]'s 37-yard field goal. The Seahawks would regain the lead in the fourth quarter with Mare's 39-yard and 46-yard field goal. However, the Bears got the last laugh as Cutler hooked up with wide receiver [[Devin Hester]] on a 36-yard touchdown pass (with a successful 2-point conversion pass to wide receiver [[Earl Bennett]]). Seattle tried to rally, but Chicago's defense held on for the win. With the loss, the Seahawks fell to 1â2. {| class="wikitable" | align="center" |- ! rowspan="2"| ! rowspan="2"| Time ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Team ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Player ! rowspan="2"| Yards of Score ! rowspan="2"| PAT ! colspan="2"| Score |- ! align="center"| SEA ! align="center"| CHI |- ! rowspan="2"| Q1 | align="center"|10:35 | align="center"|Seattle | align="center"|[[Seneca Wallace]] to [[Julius Jones]] | align="center"|39 yard Pass | align="center"|[[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 7 | align="center"| 0 |- | align="center"|0:45 | align="center"|Seattle | align="center"|[[Olindo Mare]] | align="center"|46 yard FG | | align="center"| 10 | align="center"| 0 |- ! rowspan="2"| Q2 | align="center"|12:06 | align="center"|Seattle | align="center"|[[Olindo Mare]] | align="center"|37 yard kick | | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| 0 |- | align="center"|2:00 | align="center"|Chicago | align="center"|[[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] to [[Greg Olsen (American football)|Greg Olsen]] | align="center"|1 yard pass | | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| 7 |- ! rowspan="2"| Q3 | align="center"|11:36 | align="center"|Chicago | align="center"|[[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] to [[Johnny Knox]] | align="center"|13 yard pass | align="center"|[[Robbie Gould]] kick | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| 14 |- | align="center"|5:31 | align="center"|Chicago | align="center"|[[Robbie Gould]] | align="center"|37 yard FG | | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| 17 |- ! rowspan="3"| Q4 | align="center"|14:48 | align="center"|Seattle | align="center"|[[Olindo Mare]] | align="center"|39 yard FG | | align="center"| 16 | align="center"| 17 |- | 5:12 | align="center"|Seattle | align="center"|[[Olindo Mare]] | align="center"|49 yard FG | | align="center"| 19 | align="center"| 17 |- | align="center"|1:52 | align="center"|Chicago | align="center"|[[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] to [[Devin Hester]] | align="center"|36 yard pass | align="center"|[[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] to [[Earl Bennett]] | align="center"| 19 | align="center"| 25 |- |} ===Week 4: at Indianapolis Colts=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=0||R2=3||R3=0||R4=14||RT=17 |Home='''Colts''' |H1=7||H2=14||H3=7||H4=6||HT=34 |stadium= [[Lucas Oil Stadium]], [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/10:00 AM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 63Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 66,112 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]], [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]], & Jaime Maggio }} Trying to snap a two-game losing streak, the Seahawks flew to [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] for a Week 4 inter-conference duel with the [[Indianapolis Colts]]. Seattle would trail as Colts running back [[Donald Brown (American football)|Donald Brown]] got a 1-yard touchdown run in the first quarter, followed by quarterback [[Peyton Manning]]'s 5-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Reggie Wayne]]. The Seahawks would get on the board with a 38-yard field goal from kicker [[Olindo Mare]], but Indianapolis would close out the half with Manning's 21-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Austin Collie]]. Following running back [[Joseph Addai]]'s 12-yard touchdown run in the third quarter, the Colts would seal the win with kicker [[Adam Vinatieri]]'s 37-yard and 19-yard field goals. Seattle would end the game with quarterback [[Seneca Wallace]] getting a 1-yard touchdown run and completing a 1-yard touchdown pass to fullback [[Owen Schmitt]]. With the loss, the Seahawks fell to 1â3. ===Week 5: vs. Jacksonville Jaguars=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Jaguars |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home='''Seahawks''' |H1=3||H2=17||H3=14||H4=7||HT=0 |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/1:15 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 65Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 67,228 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} After missing two weeks with cracked ribs, quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] played for the first time since week two at San Francisco. Trying to snap a three-game losing streak, Hasselbeck started the offense off quickly, with [[Olindo Mare]] completing two field goals to put Seattle up by 6. The Seahawks defense also held its own, including a 4th-and-2 stop when the Jaguars threaten to score in the red zone. Later in the 2nd quarter, Hasselbeck would find wide receiver [[T.J. Houshmandzadeh]] for his first touchdown of the year, putting Seattle up 13â0. On their next offensive drive, Hasselbeck would connect with [[Nate Burleson]] for another touchdown, extending their lead to 20â0, which they took into halftime. Starting the third quarter on offense, [[David Garrard]] and the Jaguars tried to put some points on the board. However, all of their hopes were dashed when defensive end [[Cory Redding]] recovered a key fumble for 26 yards. Taking advantage of this, Hasselbeck again found Houshmandzadeh for his second touchdown to seal the game at 27â0. The Seahawks would later score again as Matt Hasselbeck threw his fourth touchdown again to Burleson, while defensive end [[Nick Reed]] scored from 79 yards out from a fumble recovery, putting the Seahawks up 41â0. With the win, the Seahawks improved to 2â3 for the season. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| ! rowspan="2"| Time ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Team ! rowspan="2"| Scoring Player ! rowspan="2"| Yards of Score ! rowspan="2"| PAT ! colspan="2"| Score |- ! align="center"| SEA ! align="center"| JAX |- ! rowspan="1"| Q1 | 6:24 | Seattle | [[Olindo Mare]] | 47 yard FG | | align="center"| 3 | align="center"| 0 |- ! rowspan="3"| Q2 | 8:03 | Seattle | [[Olindo Mare]] | 27 yard FG | | align="center"| 6 | align="center"| 0 |- | 4:43 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[T. J. Houshmandzadeh]] | 34 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 13 | align="center"| 0 |- | 2:08 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[Nate Burleson]] | 44 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 20 | align="center"| 0 |- ! rowspan="2"| Q3 | 10:08 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[T. J. Houshmandzadeh]] | 13 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 27 | align="center"| 0 |- | 5:54 | Seattle | [[Matt Hasselbeck]] to [[Nate Burleson]] | 5 yard pass | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 34 | align="center"| 0 |- ! rowspan="1"| Q4 | 14:01 | Seattle | [[Nick Reed]] | 79 yard fumble ret. | [[Olindo Mare]] kick | align="center"| 41 | align="center"| 0 |} ===Week 6: vs. Arizona Cardinals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Cardinals''' |R1=14||R2=3||R3=7||R4=3||RT=27 |Home=Seahawks |H1=0||H2=3||H3=0||H4=0||HT=3 |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/1:05 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]] |weather= 58Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 67,588 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Chris Myers]] & [[Brian Billick]] }} Fresh off their dominating win over the Jaguars, the Seahawks stayed at home for a Week 6 NFC West duel with the [[Arizona Cardinals]]. Seattle would trail in the first quarter as Cardinals quarterback [[Kurt Warner]] completed a 2-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Larry Fitzgerald]], followed by running back [[Tim Hightower]]'s 2-yard touchdown run. Arizona would increase its lead in the second quarter with a 29-yard field goal from kicker [[Neil Rackers]]. The Seahawks would then get on the board as kicker [[Olindo Mare]] nailed a 28-yard field goal. However, the Cardinals took control in the second half as Warner found wide receiver [[Steve Breaston]] on a 16-yard touchdown pass in the third quarter, followed by Rackers' 31-yard field goal in the fourth. With the loss, Seattle went into their bye week at 2â4. ===Week 7: BYE=== ===Week 8: at Dallas Cowboys=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=3||R2=7||R3=0||R4=7||RT=17 |Home='''Cowboys''' |H1=7||H2=14||H3=14||H4=3||HT=38 |stadium= [[Cowboys Stadium]], [[Arlington, Texas]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/10:00 AM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= None (Dome Closed) |attendance= 80,886 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} Hoping to rebound from their divisional home loss to the Cardinals, the Seahawks flew to [[Cowboys Stadium]] for a Week 8 showdown with the [[Dallas Cowboys]]. In the first quarter, Seattle struck first as kicker [[Olindo Mare]] got a 43-yard field goal. However, the Cowboys answered with quarterback [[Tony Romo]]'s 36-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Sam Hurd]]. Dallas would increase their lead in the second quarter with a 2-yard touchdown run from running back [[Marion Barber III|Marion Barber]]. The Seahawks would reply with quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] completing a 23-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Deion Branch]], but Dallas came right back with Romo finding wide receiver [[Roy Williams (wide receiver)|Roy Williams]] on a 7-yard touchdown pass. The Cowboys took a huge lead with Romo's 3-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Miles Austin]], followed by wide receiver [[Patrick Crayton]] returning a punt 82 yards for a touchdown. In the fourth quarter, Dallas closed out its scoring with a 40-yard field goal from kicker [[Nick Folk]]. Seattle tried to rally, but could only muster up Hasslebeck's 4-yard touchdown pass to fullback [[Justin Griffith]]. With the loss, the Seahawks fell to 2â5. ===Week 9: vs. Detroit Lions=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=17||R2=0||R3=0||R4=3||RT=20 |Home='''Seahawks''' |H1=0||H2=13||H3=9||H4=10|HT=32 |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle Washington]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/1:05 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= 48Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 67,003 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} Trying to snap a two-game losing streak, the Seahawks went home for a Week 9 duel with the [[Detroit Lions]]. Seattle would trail in the first quarter as Lions quarterback [[Matthew Stafford]] completed a 7-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Brandon Pettigrew]] and a 29-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Bryant Johnson]], followed by kicker [[Jason Hanson]] getting a 41-yard field goal. Seattle would answer in the second quarter as running back [[Julius Jones]] got a 3-yard touchdown run, followed by kicker [[Olindo Mare]] nailing a pair of 37-yard field goals. In the third quarter, the Seahawks took the lead as Mare got a 24-yard field goal, while quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] hooked up with wide receiver [[T. J. Houshmandzadeh|T.J. Houshmandzadeh]] on a 2-yard touchdown pass (with a failed two-point conversion). Seattle would increase their lead in the fourth quarter as Mare booted a 20-yard field goal. Detroit tried to rally as Hanson made a 50-yard field goal, yet the Seahawks would end the game with cornerback [[Josh Wilson (American football)|Josh Wilson]] returning an interception 61 yards for a touchdown. With the win, Seattle improved to 3â5. ===Week 10: at Arizona Cardinals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=7||R2=10||R3=0||R4=3||RT=20 |Home='''Cardinals''' |H1=0||H2=10||H3=7||H4=14||HT=31 |stadium= [[University of Phoenix Stadium]], [[Glendale, Arizona]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/1:15 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= None (Dome Closed) |attendance= 62,278 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} Coming off their home win over the Lions, the Seahawks flew to the [[University of Phoenix Stadium]] for a Week 10 NFC West rematch with the [[Arizona Cardinals]]. Seattle took flight in the first quarter as running back [[Justin Forsett]] got an 11-yard touchdown run. The Seahawks would add onto their lead in the second quarter with quarterback [[Matt Hasselbeck]] completing a 31-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[John Carlson (American football)|John Carlson]]. The Cardinals would answer with quarterback [[Kurt Warner]] completing a 28-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Steve Breaston]], yet Seattle came right back with a 32-yard field goal from kicker [[Olindo Mare]]. Arizona would close out the half with kicker [[Neil Rackers]] nailing a 27-yard field goal. In the third quarter, the Cardinals would tie the game with running back [[Beanie Wells|Chris "Beanie" Wells]] getting a 10-yard touchdown run. The Seahawks would respond in the fourth quarter as Mare booted a 20-yard field goal, but Arizona got the last laugh as Wells picked up a 13-yard touchdown run and Warner hooked up with wide receiver [[Larry Fitzgerald]] on an 18-yard touchdown pass. With the loss, Seattle fell to 3â6. ===Week 11: at Minnesota Vikings=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=0||R2=0||R3=3||R4=6||RT=9 |Home='''Vikings''' |H1=0||H2=21||H3=7||H4=7||HT=35 |stadium= [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]], [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/10:00 AM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= None (Dome Stadium) |attendance= 63,854 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} Hoping to rebound from their loss to the Cardinals, the Seahawks flew to the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome for a Inter conference Duel with the [[Minnesota Vikings]]. Seattle trailed early in the second quarter when QB [[Brett Favre]] completed three touchdown passes: One to WR [[Percy Harvin]] for 23 yards, TE [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] for 8 yards and then to WR [[Bernard Berrian]] for 3 yards. Then in the third quarter the margin increased as Favre hooked up with WR [[Sidney Rice]] on a 7-yard touchdown pass. Then Seattle's kicker [[Olindo Mare]] got a 40-yard field goal to avoid a shutout loss. In the fourth quarter the margin increased even further as QB [[Tarvaris Jackson]] made a 34-yard touchdown pass to WR [[Sidney Rice]], then Seattle has their first touchdown of this game when RB [[Justin Forsett]] made a 1-yard run (With a failed 2-point conversion attempt). With the loss, Seattle fell to 3â7. ===Week 12: at St. Louis Rams=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Seahawks''' |R1=7||R2=7||R3=3||R4=10||RT=27 |Home=Rams |H1=0||H2=10||H3=0||H4=7||HT=17 |stadium= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]], [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] & [[Nischelle Turner]] }} ===Week 13: vs. [[Chris Myers]], [[Ross Tucker]] & [[Jaime Maggio]] }} ===Week 14: at Houston Texans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=0||R2=7||R3=0||R4=0||RT=7 |Home='''Texans''' |H1=17||H2=7||H3=10||H4=0||HT=34 |stadium= [[Reliant Stadium]], [[Houston, Texas]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/10:00 AM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= 50Â°F (Cloudy) {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Buccaneers''' |R1=0||R2=3||R3=18||R4=3||RT= |Home=Seahawks |H1=0||H2=7||H3=0||H4=0|HT= |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North |TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]], [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] & [[Nischelle Turner]] }} ===Week 16: at Green Bay Packers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=0||R2=0||R3=3||R4=7|RT= |Home='''Packers''' |H1=14||H2=10||H3=14||H4=10||HT= |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/10:00 AM [[Pacific Time zone|PST]] |weather= 18Â°F(Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,429 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]] & [[Brian Billick]] }} ===Week 17: vs. Tennessee Titans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Titans''' |R1=7||R2=0||R3=3||R4=7||RT= |Home=Seahawks |H1=0||H2=7||H3=3||H4=3||HT= |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/1:15 PM [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |weather= 44 Â°F (Overcast) |attendance= 67,002 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] became the sixth player in NFL history to break 2,000 rushing yards and also broke the record (held by [[Marshall Faulk]]) of total yards from scrimmage at 2,509. Johnson rushed 36 times for 134 yards and two touchdowns; a 64-yard rushing score was called back on a holding penalty.
